A **cornuthaum** is a type of [magical](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item") [helm](/wiki/Helm "Helm") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [cloth](/wiki/Cloth "Cloth"), and appears as a [conical hat](/wiki/Conical_hat "Conical hat") when unidentified, an appearance that it shares with the [dunce cap](/wiki/Dunce_cap "Dunce cap").

## Generation

In addition to random generation, general [stores](/wiki/Store "Store") and used armor dealerships can sell cornuthaums.

## Description

While worn, a cornuthaum provides [MC1](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation") but no base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC"). [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") wearing a cornuthaum gain 1 point of [charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") and extrinsic [clairvoyance](/wiki/Clairvoyance "Clairvoyance"); non-Wizards lose 1 point of charisma and have all sources of clairvoyance blocked (whether from the intrinsic or the [spell](/wiki/Spellbook_of_clairvoyance "Spellbook of clairvoyance")). Wizards alone can safely enchant a cornuthaum from +5 or lower, while other roles risk destroying one if it is enchanted while above +3.

## Strategy

Cornuthaums are among the best helms for Wizards, being the only permanent source of clairvoyance outside of the [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor"). They are are often overlooked in favor of the [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance"), since a potential +4 or +5 bonus to [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") and [wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") has far more applications in most situations than the cornuthaum's +1 charisma bonus. Wizards finding a cornuthaum close to the start of the game may even prefer an [orcish helm](/wiki/Orcish_helm "Orcish helm") for protection from [falling rock traps](/wiki/Falling_rock_trap "Falling rock trap"), at least until they can gain a few levels and raise their HP.

From the point that most Wizards are prepared to delve deeper into the dungeon, a cornuthaum is generally preferable by far for navigating the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines") and other dark areas, even for races with [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") - most Wizards start with more than enough innate intelligence to cast low-level spells often (especially [elven](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)") Wizards), and can raise their intelligence via [alchemized](/wiki/Alchemy "Alchemy") [potions of gain ability](/wiki/Potion_of_gain_ability "Potion of gain ability") if necessary. [Orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") Wizards may occasionally prefer the helm of brilliance for fully [hungerless casting](/wiki/Hungerless_casting "Hungerless casting"), but their normal cap of 16 Int will suffice for a majority of standard scenarios.

While Wizards can safely enchant a cornuthaum to +7 similar to an [elven leather helm](/wiki/Elven_leather_helm "Elven leather helm"), the [scrolls of enchant armor](/wiki/Scroll_of_enchant_armor "Scroll of enchant armor") required are better spent elsewhere in their mid-to-late game, especially once they obtain [The Eye of the Aethiopica](/wiki/The_Eye_of_the_Aethiopica "The Eye of the Aethiopica") and gain the [power](/wiki/Power "Power") regeneration necessary to make frequent use of higher-level spells. A +5 helm of brilliance can provide the benefits of boosted intelligence and wisdom at only 1 less point of AC than a +7 cornuthaum; patient Wizards can also [polypile](/wiki/Polypile "Polypile") their way to a +6 or +7 helm of brilliance using the aforementioned scrolls and readily-available elven armor.

The cornuthaum is the only MC-granting armor that is not worn on the torso, and is the only source of MC for an intelligent [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid") [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") that is [too large](/wiki/Physical_size "Physical size") to wear body armor, e.g. a [titan](/wiki/Titan "Titan") or [centaur](/wiki/Centaur_\(monster_class\) "Centaur (monster class)") - monsters such as [Archons](/wiki/Archon "Archon") that inherently have MC1 gain no further protection from a cornuthaum outside of its enchantment.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Large humanoids such as giants and other similar monsters can now wear [mummy wrappings](/wiki/Mummy_wrapping "Mummy wrapping"), which also grant MC1.

### Identification

As the cornuthaum and the [autocursing](/wiki/Autocursing "Autocursing") dunce cap are both conical hats, picking up and wear-testing a conical hat at random is a [Bad Idea](/wiki/Bad_Idea "Bad Idea"). They can easily be [distinguished by price](/wiki/Price_identification "Price identification"): the cornuthaum has a base cost of 80 zorkmids.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

For a [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist"), 1⁄3 of conical hats can be read. A cornuthaum will be labeled "WIZZARD".

## History

The cornuthaum first appears in [NetHack 3.2.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.0 "NetHack 3.2.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including variants derived from those versions, cornuthaums grant [MC2](/wiki/Magic_cancellation_\(3.4.3\) "Magic cancellation (3.4.3)") while worn, making them more useful as MC sources for pets and as Archon hats in particular.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Pointed hat](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pointed_hat "wikipedia:Pointed hat")***

"Cornuthaum" is a term coined by *NetHack* [DevTeam](/wiki/DevTeam "DevTeam") member Janet Walz to describe the stereotypical conical, pointed hat associated with traditional depictions of [wizards and other magicians](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magician_\(fantasy\) "wikipedia:Magician (fantasy)") in fictional media[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) - *cornu* is Latin for "horn", and *thauma* (θαῦμα) is Greek for "miracle, wonder".

Among the most common forms of wizard hat is the conical blue hat covered with yellow stars and crescent moons; their shape and decoration are likely based on golden hats found during archeological digs in Europe that are adorned with astronomical sequences, and have been speculated as being worn by ancient wizards. Most other types of headwear that wizards and other magicians are depicted with will be at least conical in shape, and may even resemble a [witch hat](/wiki/Witch_hat "Witch hat"). The notion of a thinking hat may also derive from ceremonial conical hats, or even "true" thinking hats.

## Messages

- You sense a pointy hat on top of your head.

  You cast the [spell of clairvoyance](/wiki/Spell_of_clairvoyance "Spell of clairvoyance") while wearing a cornuthaum, but you are not a Wizard.

## Variants

Some variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions retain the cornuthaum's MC2.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [upgrading](/wiki/Upgrading "Upgrading") a cornuthaum produces a dunce cap and vice versa.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), the cornuthaum grants 0 base AC, 0 DR and MC2 while worn.

[Incantifiers](/wiki/Incantifier_\(starting_race\) "Incantifier (starting race)") can gain the same positive effects from a worn cornuthaum as Wizards.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), the [Dark One](/wiki/Dark_One "Dark One") has a 1⁄4 chance of generating with a cornuthaum, and [Neferet the Green](/wiki/Neferet_the_Green "Neferet the Green") and the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") always generate with a cornuthaum. One of the preset kits for a level 20 [player monster](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") includes a cornuthaum as the helm.

A uncursed cornuthaum is generated atop a wizard [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") on the second level of the [Ice Queen's Realm](/wiki/Ice_Queen%27s_Realm "Ice Queen's Realm").

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM changes, the [Flame Mage](/wiki/Flame_Mage "Flame Mage"), [Ice Mage](/wiki/Ice_Mage "Ice Mage"), [Electric Mage](/wiki/Electric_Mage "Electric Mage"), and [Acid Mage](/wiki/Acid_Mage "Acid Mage") roles gain a +1 bonus to charisma when wearing a cornuthaum, though clairvoyance is still blocked for non-Wizards; Wizards gain a +2 bonus instead.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), upgrading a cornuthaum can produce a dunce cap and vice versa, as in SLASH'EM.

## Encyclopedia entry

He was dressed in a flowing gown with fur tippets which had  
the signs of the zodiac embroidered over it, with various  
cabalistic signs, such as triangles with eyes in them, queer  
crosses, leaves of trees, bones of birds and animals, and a  
planetarium whose stars shone like bits of looking-glass with  
the sun on them. He had a pointed hat like a dunce's cap, or  
like the headgear worn by ladies of that time, except that  
the ladies were accustomed to have a bit of veil floating  
from the top of it.

\[ The Once and Future King, by T.H. White ]

  


         "A wizard!" Dooley exclaimed, astounded.  
         "At your service, sirs," said the wizard. "How  
perceptive of you to notice. I suppose my hat rather gives me  
away. Something of a beacon, I don't doubt." His hat was  
pretty much that, tall and cone-shaped with stars and crescent  
moons all over it. All in all, it couldn't have been more  
wizardish.

\[ The Elfin Ship, James P. Blaylock ]

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/objects.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 349](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/objects.c#L349)

[[Incantifier (starting race)|Incantifiers]] can gain the same positive effects from a worn cornuthaum as Wizards. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], the [[Dark One]] has a {{frac|4}} chance of generating with a cornuthaum, and [[Neferet the Green]] and the [[Wizard of Yendor]] always generate with a cornuthaum. One of the preset kits for a level 20 [[player monster]] includes a cornuthaum as the helm. A uncursed cornuthaum is generated atop a wizard [[corpse]] on the second level of the [[Ice Queen's Realm]]. ===SlashTHEM=== In [[SlashTHEM]], in addition to SLASH'EM changes, the [[Flame Mage]], [[Ice Mage]], [[Electric Mage]], and [[Acid Mage]] roles gain a +1 bonus to charisma when wearing a cornuthaum, though clairvoyance is still blocked for non-Wizards; Wizards gain a +2 bonus instead. ===Hack'EM=== In [[Hack'EM]], upgrading a cornuthaum can produce a dunce cap and vice versa, as in SLASH'EM. ==Encyclopedia entry== {{encyclopedia| He was dressed in a flowing gown with fur tippets which had the signs of the zodiac embroidered over it, with various cabalistic signs, such as triangles with eyes in them, queer crosses, leaves of trees, bones of birds and animals, and a planetarium whose stars shone like bits of looking-glass with the sun on them. He had a pointed hat like a dunce's cap, or like the headgear worn by ladies of that time, except that the ladies were accustomed to have a bit of veil floating from the top of it. {{right-align|[ The Once and Future King, by T.H. White ]}} "A wizard!" Dooley exclaimed, astounded. "At your service, sirs," said the wizard. "How perceptive of you to notice. I suppose my hat rather gives me away. Something of a beacon, I don't doubt." His hat was pretty much that, tall and cone-shaped with stars and crescent moons all over it. All in all, it couldn't have been more wizardish. {{right-align|[ The Elfin Ship, James P. Blaylock ]}} }} ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Helms]]
